title: Gaura Mandala Parikrama | Srinivasa Acharya: His Birth & Spiritual Legacy | Sri Jai Chaitanya Dasa
speaker: HG Jai Chaitanya Dasa

segments.key_quote: Srinivas Acharya was born in 1530 A.D. On the full moon day of the month of Vaisakha, in the village of Chakhandi, in the district of Nadia.
segments.summary: This segment describes the birth details of Srinivas Acharya, including the year, month, location, and his father's background.
segments.transcript: Srinivas Acharya was born in 1530 A.D. on the full moon day of the month of Vaisakha, in the village of Chakhandi, in the district of Nadia,

segments.key_quote: When other devotees saw him intoxicated in divine love for Mahaprabhu, they nicknamed him Chaitanya Das, a name that stuck with him for the rest of his life.
segments.summary: This segment focuses on Srinivas Acharya's father, Gangadhar Bhattacharya, his intense devotion to Mahaprabhu, and how he received the name Chaitanya Das.
segments.transcript: his father, Gangadhar Bhattacharya, was a Brahmin of the Rarha class. The Bhakti Ratnakara describes the event as follows. When Mahaprabhu took sannyas in Kathua, Gangadhar Bhattacharya was overcome with grief and began to cry constantly while calling out the names, Ha Chaitanya, Ha Chaitanya. When other devotees saw him intoxicated in divine love for Mahaprabhu, they nicknamed him Chaitanya Das, a name that stuck with him for the rest of his life. Chaitanya Dasa had no desire for the things of this world.

segments.key_quote: Indeed, his wife will give birth to a jewel of a son, who will be named Srinivas. He will be the manifest form of my love and will be non-different from me.
segments.summary: This segment narrates the story of how Chaitanya Dasa and his wife sought Mahaprabhu's blessings for a son, and Mahaprabhu's prophecy about the birth and future role of Srinivas.
segments.transcript: But one day, he suddenly felt a strong wish to have a son and told this to his wife, Leshmipriya. She responded by telling him to immediately go to Puri and ask Mahaprabhu for his blessings. The couple left for Puri, stopping for a few days at the house of Balaram Vibhra, Leshmipriya's father, in Jaji Gram. When they arrived in Puri, Chaitanya Dasa and his wife paid their obeisances to Mahaprabhu. But before they could speak, the Lord himself said, understanding their desire, Jagannath Deva will surely fulfill all your desires. The other devotees were curious about what desire Mahaprabhu was talking about, and they asked his servant Govinda. But before he could say anything, Mahaprabhu called Govinda and gave him the answer. Chaitanya Dasa decides to have a son. Indeed, his wife will give birth to a jewel of a son, who will be named Srinivas. He will be the manifest form of my love and will be non-different from me. He will increase everyone's love. He will increase everyone's enthusiasm for devotion. Through Rupa and others, I will bring scriptures into the world, and through Srinivas, I shall distribute them.

segments.key_quote: Once they had received Mahaprabhu's blessing, Chaitanya Dasa and his wife returned to his home, and when the auspicious moment came, a son was born to them.
segments.summary: This segment describes the birth of Srinivas, his early devotion, his education, the death of his father, and the subsequent move to his maternal grandfather's house.
segments.transcript: Once they had received Mahaprabhu's blessing, Chaitanya Dasa and his wife returned to his home, and when the auspicious moment came, a son was born to them. Chaitanya Dasa immediately offered the child to Mahaprabhu. Srinivas Acharya was devoted to his parents. He was fortunate to hear about both Mahaprabhu's divine glories as well as Radha and Krishna's Vrindavan pastimes from his father. The two of them would go into an ecstatic state as they discussed these transcendental topics. Srinivas's mother trained him in Kirtan. He studied grammar, literature, and poetic theory from Dhananjaya Vidya Vachaspati and quickly acquired mastery of these subjects. Not long afterwards, Srinivas's father died. The loss of his devotee father's association greatly affected Srinivas, so he made a concerted effort to console him and his mother in their grief. segments.key_quote: Before arriving in Puri, however, the news arrived that Mahaprabhu had indeed ended his Leela. Srinivas Acharya fainted at the news and when he came back to consciousness, he decided to commit suicide.
segments.summary: This segment recounts Srinivas's journey to Puri, the news of Mahaprabhu's disappearance, his despair and suicidal thoughts, and how the Lord appeared to him in a dream.
segments.transcript: where the villagers were overjoyed to see him. Srinivas went to visit Narahari Sarkar in nearby Srikanta. From Narahari, he learned that Mahaprabhu would shortly be ending his earthly pastimes. This news made Srinivas determined to see the Lord before it happened. He quickly returned to Jajigram and took permission from his mother to make a trip to Puri. He then joined the devotees on the annual pilgrimage. It was the fifth day of the waxing moon. Before arriving in Puri, however, the news arrived that Mahaprabhu had indeed ended his Leela. Srinivas Acharya fainted at the news, and when he came back to consciousness, he decided to commit suicide. However, the Lord himself appeared to him in a dream and told him to complete his journey to Puri. Once in Puri, he again had a dream in which he saw Jagannath, Subhadra, and Baladev, as well as Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, with his associates. The incarnation of Mahaprabhu's pleasure potency, Srila Gadhadara Pandit Goswami, met him, and both of them were immersed in an ocean of ecstasy. Srinivas also met Raya Ramananda, Paramananda Puri, Sakhi Mahayati, Sarvabhauma Bhatt, Shikhi Mahayati, Sarvabhauma Pandit, Prakreshwara Pandit, and Srinivas Acharya. They met Govinda, Shankara Pandit, Gopinath Acharya and received blessings from them all. Srinivas Acharya stayed for some time in Puri, hearing Srimad Bhagavatam from Gadhadara Pandit Goswami. Gadhadara then told him to return to Gouda. When Srinivas returned, he heard that Advaita Acharya and Nityananda Prabhu had also disappeared. Once again, he determined to end his life, but the two Prabhus appeared to him in a dream

segments.key_quote: When he arrived in Navadvipa, Srinivas was once again plunged into a morose of sorrow at the loss of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu.
segments.summary: This segment describes Srinivas's experiences in Navadvipa, receiving blessings from Vishnupriya Devi and Satchi Devi, his tour of Bengal, and his request for permission to go to Vrindavan.
segments.transcript: and had him give up his intention. When he arrived in Navadvipa, Srinivas was once again plunged into a morose of sorrow at the loss of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. Vamshi Vadanananda Gotthakur saw him in this condition and approached Vishnupriya Devi and asked her to grant an audience to Srinivas and bless him. Srinivas Acharya was amazed to see the intense renunciation and deep faith of Mahaprabhu's widow. While in Navadvipa, he had a dream of Satchi Devi and received blessings from her too. Srinivas then wandered throughout Bengal, going to all the associates of Mahaprabhu and Nityananda Prabhu, seeking their blessings. He visited Shantipur, Kardaha, Kanakula, Krishnanagar, Srikanta, etc., met Murari Gupta, Sivasa Pandit, Damodara Pandit, Shukkaam Brahma Brahmachari, Gadadhar Das, Parameshwari Das, Jnanava Devi, Vasudha Devi, Veerabhadra, Averam Thakur, Narahari Sarkar Thakur, Raghunandan Thakur. All these great personalities witnessed Srinivas' intense devotion and told him to go to Vrindavana. Srinivas then went to his mother and asked her repeatedly for permission to make the trip to Vrindavan,

segments.key_quote: He was initiated by Gopalabhatta and took instruction in the Vaishnava scriptures from Jeeva.
segments.summary: This segment details Srinivas's journey to Vrindavan, his meetings with various Goswamis, his initiation by Gopalabhatta, receiving instructions from Jeeva Goswami, and being tasked with taking manuscripts back to Bengal.
segments.transcript: which she could not refuse when she saw his great eagerness. Srinivasa then travelled through Agra, Dvipa, Khatva, Maureshwara, Eka Chakra to Kashi, Ayodhya and Prayag. He spent a long time travelling and visiting all these holy places before finally arriving at Vraja. There he heard that Rupa Goswami, Sanatan Goswami, Kashi Shwara Pandit and Raghunath Bhatta Goswami had all disappeared. Raghunath Das Goswami, Gopalabhatta Goswami and Jeeva Goswami were still living. However, Srinivas met all three of them and received their blessings. He was initiated by Gopalabhatta and took instruction in the Vaishnava scriptures from Jeeva. In great affection for Srinivasa, Jeeva commended him to his deities, Radha Dhamodara. Srinivasa met Raghunath Das and Krishna Das Kaviraj in Radha Kunda and received their blessings. One day, Sri Jeeva heard Srinivasa explain a verse from Ujjwala Ninamani and was so impressed by his erudition that he bestowed the title Acharya upon him. Jeeva also gave the title Thakur to Narottama and Shamananda and the name Shamananda to Dukkhi Krishna Das. Jeeva ordered Srinivas to tour the sites of pilgrimages in Braja area with Raghava Goswami. After Srinivas had attained mastery of the Gaudiya Vaishnava scriptures, Sri Jeeva and other Vaishnavas in Braja ordered him, Narottama and Srinivas to take manuscripts of these most remembered scriptures.

segments.summary: This segment narrates the theft of the manuscripts by the king of Vishnupura, his disappointment upon finding only books, and the astrologer's confusion over his incorrect predictions.
segments.transcript: valuable books back to bangal in an ox cart. It was a long and dangerous trip, but they were able to cover the greater part of the distance without any trouble. Upon arriving in the Hindu kingdom of Pana Vishnupura, they felt that the danger was over. However, the rumor had reached the capital of Vishnupura that a rich merchant was traveling to Pulli with a valuable cargo of merchandise. The ruler of the kingdom led a gang of highwaymen, and when he heard that a cargo of great value was passing through his kingdom, he asked an astrologer to divine the truth of the rumors. The astrologer confirmed that this was indeed a cargo of great value. The king immediately sent a group of robbers to steal it, specifying that they should kill no one. The robbers first worshipped the goddess Chandi, then sent out a spy who returned to tell them that everyone in the group accompanying the ox-cart was sleeping in exhaustion. After eating their night meal, the robbers thought that this was surely Chandi's mercy, that a golden opportunity like this had come their way. They seized the ox-cart and the books, thinking they were gold and jewels, and turned them over to the king. When Vishnupura's king saw the large chest, he was delighted at the prospect of finding a large amount of valuables inside. How disappointed he must have been to see nothing but books inside. He turned to the astrologer and asked him how he could have made such a mistake. The astrologer answered, "I cannot understand it. Every time I made my calculation, it came up with the same conclusion. This chest is full of priceless jewels. It is incredible. I don't know why my calculations have gone wrong. segments.key_quote: The mere sight of the holy books had a purifying effect on the king.
segments.summary: This segment describes the purifying effect of the books on the king, Srinivas's arrival in Vishnupura, and his agreement to give lectures on the Bhagavata.
segments.transcript: had a purifying effect on the king. This king is King Virahambar of this place. We are in his kingdom. Be careful with any valuables you have. However, he regretted having stolen them. Indeed, he desired to meet with the acharya of the books. The next morning, Srinivasa, Narottama, and Shamananda awoke to find the chest of the books missing. They searched everywhere, but when they failed to find any clue to the books' whereabouts, they felt so depressed that they considered killing themselves. Some local villagers saw the distressed condition of the three Vaishnavas and immediately suspected the robber king Veerahambira. Srinivasa made some further investigations and was assured that he would be able to find more information about the king himself. The three Vaishnavas felt some hope and abandoned their suicidal intentions. Srinivasa Acharya decided to remain in Vishnupura in the hope of finding the books, but he sent Narottama to Keturi and Shamananda to Orissa. While staying in Vishnupura, Srinivasa heard from a Brahmin named Krishna Vallabha that Veerahambira liked to listen to Srimad Bhagavatam and daily attended classes. On the next day, Srinivasa went with his Brahmin to the hall where the Bhagavata classes were held. The Brahmin introduced Srinivasa to the king as a great Vaishnava, and the king indeed observed the characteristics of the Brahmin. The king expressed a desire to hear Srinivasa speak on the Bhagavata, and Srinivasa agreed, thinking that this might be a good opportunity to recover the books. So he started to give

segments.key_quote: The king immediately confessed, showing great sorrow for his misdeed, and had the chest of books returned to its owner.
segments.summary: This segment recounts Srinivas's captivating lectures, the different styles of Kirtan used by the acharyas, the king's confession of the theft, the return of the books, and the king's subsequent initiation by Srinivas.
segments.transcript: lectures on the Bhagavata on a daily basis. The king was enchanted by Srinivasa's unprecedented explanations of the Bhagavata in his sweet voice. Srinivasa's acharyas primarily preached Bahan Prabhu's Dharma through speaking on the Bhagavata and Kirtan, while Narottama and Shamananda primarily used the medium of Kirtan. The styles of Kirtan that these three acharyas used were named Manohara Sahi, Garana Hati, and Reneti. ViraHambira arranged for a secluded dwelling to be given to Srinivasa Acharya. One day, when he had the opportunity to find the king alone in his apartment, Srinivasa recounted the entire story of the journey from Raja and the theft of the manuscripts. The king immediately confessed, showing great sorrow for his misdeed, and had the chest of books returned to its owner. In great relief, Srinivasa immediately sent messengers to Vrindavan, Narottama, and Shamananda with the good news. In the course of time, Veerahambira and his entire entourage all took initiation from Srinivasa and dedicated their entire lives and wealth to him.
